awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Proposal: Web-based Geo-Visualization and Laboratory Integration with the Magnetics Information Consortium
awd_abstract_narration:
This award continues support for the Magnetics Information Consortium (MagIC).  The goal of MagIC is to develop and maintain an open community digital data archive for published rock and paleomagnetic data. This will allow researchers and other users continued free access to archive, search, visualize, manipulate and download these data, thereby improving research capabilities and ensuring ongoing access to previously collected data in the Earth Sciences. Since 2003, MagIC`s development has been funded by NSF as a domain-specific enterprise, and has recently transitioned to a modern system that will allow development of improved capacity to link to other data collections necessary to harness data addressing significant long term research problems in paleomagnetic and rock magnetic research. These include (i) understanding of past climate changes and their relation to the Earth`s magnetic field; (ii) the timing of the appearance and growth of the Earth`s solid inner core and the associated influences on the geomagnetic field; (iii) the geodynamics of the Earth`s mantle, where magnetic data are crucial in determining the fixity of mantle plumes and the possibility of true polar wander, (iv) biogeomagnetism, and (v) magnetism at high pressures and in extra-terrestrial bodies, including other planets. MagIC provides fundamental tools online for data interpretation and geo-visualization. Training of the next generation in the development and use of modern data analysis methods is a key component of this initiative.
 
A major overhaul of MagIC`s architecture has been undertaken, including transitioning to the open source GitHub repository so that community input can drive software development. The database backend (using MongoDB and Elasticsearch) and web interface (using Meteor with React and Semantic UI) have been completely rewritten and the underlying data model (now version 3.0) has been drastically simplified. Flexible procedures for archiving data via web interfaces have been developed to improve the user experience and address the needs of the paleomagnetic and rock magnetic community. This has been a drastic effort, but the new architecture is ready for expanded business. Modern scientific efforts require efficient access to data, transparency in data processing, and reliable documentation so that questions of reproducibility and standardization can be readily addressed. A key aspect of our past and future work is the establishment of individualized workflow schemas for understanding all aspects of any study from field metadata, through lab measurements, and interpreted results. This facilitates integration of data from disparate studies, and gives full control to the data user in determining data quality and suitability for specific purposes. It is also rapidly developing into a requirement for geoscience publications. Work under this proposal will focus on five areas: (i) assisting paleomagnetic labs in development and implementation of transparent workflow strategies to archive their data; (ii) adding new search, visualization, and API features to MagIC; (iii) interoperability with other magnetics databases; (iv) additions to PmagPy data processing tools, including reproducibility via the use of Jupyter notebooks; (v) making make other data sources, such as IODP, accessible in MagIC; (vi) data rescue operations to ensure that valuable existing information is not lost to future researchers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Magnetics Information Consortium (http://earthref.org/MAGIC) was established during the PMAG 2002 Workshop, following early discussions starting in 2000 of a community vision for MagIC. This online facility has been developed under a series of collaborative NSF proposals since 2003 and this is its fifth grant cycle sponsored by EAR Geoinformatics. 

The goals of MagIC are to improve research capacity in the Earth sciences, by maintaining an open community digital data archive for rock and paleomagnetic data with web portals that allow users free access to archive, search, visualize, and download these data. MagIC supports the international rock and paleomagnetic communities and strives to bring data out of researchers’ private archives and personal computers, making them accessible to everybody and useable for new creative and collaborative activities.

 At the end of this program cycle in mid-December 2022, data from more than >4,600 publications (up by 400) reside in the MagIC Database including data from >245,000 wordlwide geological sites (up by 65,000) and >9,300,000 measurements (up by 4,300,000) from over 290,000 experiments (up by 220,000). These data have been provided through 150 unique contributors (up by 100) with some data sets still in private mode, awaiting activation by these researchers. MagIC over the years has established a strong user base of researchers, teachers and students, and a wealth of data that is effectively discoverable via EarthRef.org, EarthCUBE initiatives, and Earth Science Publishers.

MagIC now has transitioned completely to an Elasticsearch, MongoDB, Meteor and React based thick client website technology stack. Over the last three years, we have capitilized majorly on this technology transition and we have been able to make major progress, as is reflected in the huge step up in users and data contributed and downloaded.

The MagIC Website Application is deployed to Docker containers that are now orchestrated with Kubernetes and integrate almost wholesale with Amazon Web Services. MagIC now also integrates and its contents are served with schema.org and JSON-LD so it can be indexed by Google Search, EarthCUBE's Project 418/419, and other online entities.

In 2022, 65.0 contributions on average were being worked on by 36.8 contributors each month, which reflects an 81% increase over the average in 2017. The persistence of users on the MagIC website mimics those strong increases, with long sessions by single users (defined as at least 3 minutes) sharply increasing from 2,220 in 2017 to 6,037 in 2022. Contribution activity has also increased significantly from datasets containing an average of 583 worldwide sites per month in 2014 to 19,055 in 2022. The same is true for contributions containing on average 57,000 magnetic measurements per month in 2014 to 388,000 in 2022, a sharp 580% increase.

Over the last three years, 331 new datasets were added of which 196 include measurement level data crucial for the reproducibility of the research. These contributions included 3.26 billion raster points from 7,500 SQUID microscopy and XPEEM experiments.

Finally, MagIC downloads increased from 526 in 2014 to 5,105 in 2022 not counting downloads from search subsets and API downloads. MagIC also now is cited in 359 peer-reviewed publications as per Google Scholar, and since the publication of the Tauxe et al. (2016) PmagPy paper in G-cubed, it has been cited 216 times with more than 45 citations per year on average over the last two years, showing PmagPy and MagIC have become an integral open-source software that is heavily used (and re-used) within the geosciences domain.


Last Modified: 02/05/2023
Modified by: Anthony Koppers

The same is true for contributions containing on average 57,000 magnetic measurements per month in 2014 to 388,000 in 2022, a sharp 580% increase.
